title: 109_hr898
content: The Act is titled the "Stroke Treatment and Ongoing Prevention Act" and includes amendments to the Public Health Service Act regarding stroke programs, specifically focusing on stroke education, information, and data collection programs. This includes a stroke prevention and education campaign. The Secretary is required to conduct an education and information campaign to promote stroke prevention and encourage immediate treatment for stroke patients. This includes public service announcements about stroke warning signs, prevention education, and other activities to increase awareness and prompt care-seeking behavior. The campaign's effectiveness will be measured as part of the implementation process. The Secretary will measure public awareness before the campaign, establish benchmarks, and evaluate the impact every 2 years. Efforts will not duplicate existing stroke education initiatives, and consultation with experts will be conducted. The Paul Coverdell National Acute Stroke Registry and Clearinghouse is established. The Secretary maintains the Paul Coverdell National Acute Stroke Registry by developing data points, collecting information on care achievements, and carrying out useful activities to reflect advances in stroke care. The term 'stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack' involving interrupted blood flow or a ruptured blood vessel in the brain. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 for medical professional development in advanced stroke and traumatic injury treatment and prevention. The Secretary may grant funds for residency and professional training programs in emergency medicine to improve stroke and traumatic injury care. Grants are also available for education programs on new diagnostic approaches and therapies for healthcare professionals. The Secretary grants funds for training programs in emergency medicine to improve stroke and traumatic injury care. Preference is given to entities training healthcare professionals in areas with high incidence of these conditions. Qualified entities must submit an application including a plan for rigorous evaluation of activities funded by the grant. The term 'qualified entity' refers to a consortium of public and private entities coordinating education activities among medical providers. 'Stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack' caused by interrupted blood flow or a ruptured blood vessel in the brain. The Secretary must submit a report on grant activities to relevant committees within a year. Authorization of $4,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2006-2010 to address stroke and traumatic injury. SEC. 3. Pilot project on telehealth stroke treatment. Establishment of a Telehealth Stroke Treatment Grant Program under Part D of title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may grant funds to States and consortia to conduct a 5-year pilot project from 2006 to 2010 to improve stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. The program will be administered by the Director of the Office for the Advancement of Telehealth and will involve consultation with officials from other Federal programs and experts in stroke research and care. The Secretary may grant funds to States and consortia for a 5-year pilot project to improve stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. Funds must be used for identifying entities with expertise in stroke care, establishing telehealth networks, and informing emergency medical systems. The Secretary may grant funds for a pilot project to improve stroke patient outcomes through telehealth networks. This includes informing emergency medical systems, establishing collaborative networks for stroke prevention and care, improving access to high-quality stroke care, and conducting performance evaluations. The Secretary requires States to establish a consortium of public and private entities, including universities and medical centers, to receive grants for telehealth networks. States with existing networks must agree to use them for the grant's purpose and not establish a separate network. The Secretary gives priority to grant applicants demonstrating plans to improve access to high-quality stroke care for underserved populations. Grants are limited to a maximum of 3 years and cannot extend beyond fiscal year 2010. The Secretary may award a maximum of 7 grants for the 5-year pilot project. States or consortia must apply for grants under this section. To apply for a grant under this section, a State or consortium must submit an application outlining baseline measures and benchmarks. The term 'stroke' is defined as a 'brain attack'. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006, increasing to $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, with a total of $50,000,000 authorized over five years. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the telehealth stroke treatment grant program and submit a report to Congress by March 31, 2011. The report will evaluate grant program outcomes, provide recommendations to improve stroke networks for better access to care, and suggest ways to reduce stroke incidence and complications. Recommendations on using similar telehealth grant programs to improve patient outcomes in other public health areas may be provided. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can also give interim reports to Congress on the telehealth stroke treatment grant program as needed. SEC. 4. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to set Federal standards for patient treatment or health care professional licensure.
